column3: Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/cb31ac84e50f6ae99033c8de5de540345b434eb0 for binaries and test log.\nThis test script verifies pulls every time they are updated. It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.  If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/cu

NACK. This introduces a statefulness that wouldn't work together with concurrent use of the API:

For example if we have two client, A and B.

```
A> walletpassphrase hunter2 -1
B> walletpassphrase hunter2 -1
A> sendtoaddress ...
B> sendtoaddress ...
error: {"code":-13,"...")
```
Suggestion: This might be more reasonable if it only worked with a batch request...\n
@laanwj - can it be implemented such that the wallet is only unlocked per client?\n

@rebroad I've also though about it but that's not possible. JSON RPC (as it is now) is stateless.\nA future RPC protocol with persistent connections could (probably: should) have wallet-decryption-state per client.\n

> NACK. This introduces a statefulness that wouldn't work together with concurrent use of the API:

@laanwj, you're right. I didn't even think of that. I was shortsightedly focused on solo commandline use. For now, I figure this can still be useful in situations where an assumption like this can be made though.
For solo command-line use you could make a script that wraps bitcoin-cli and does a `walletlock` immediately after every command. No need to make server-side changes.\n
